text: But the key idea here is that we're going to learn an autoencoder using graph neural nets or other techniques, where what we do is we train a model that takes a molecule graph structure and embeds that molecule graph into some low dimensional latent space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we train a model that can decode back out the molecule graph structure from this latent space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we end up with is a way of representing molecules as points in some usually 100 or so dimensional vector space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We can then train what we call a property prediction model, which tries to figure out which parts of this latent space correspond to molecules with different types of properties.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you might say, oh, this region of the latent space seems to have molecules that all interact with this particular protein that's known to be important for the COVID-19 entry process.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we can say, okay, I'm going to sample and look around in that region of latent space and decode out molecules that might be good candidates for treating COVID-19.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's a very, very difficult problem in terms of the actual machine learning engineering, but it's a problem that people are definitely making progress on in the last few years.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And again, I've given incomplete citations for some of these, but the image I've taken here is from an ACS paper by Gomez-Bombarelli et al., where they really lay out this general paradigm, not just for COVID, but for drug design in general.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The other type of approach is what we call a search or reinforcement learning-based approach.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for those of you who are interested in RL-based methods,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: or reinforcement learning and game playing is actually a really good use for these kinds of techniques.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for example, pretty similar algorithms to what you would use in the AlphaGo and other techniques that have been used to play board games like Go.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what you do here is you really treat the molecule design problem as a game, where the agent's trying to choose motifs to add to the molecule at each time step.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then the reward is how good is this molecule at, say, binding or docking to different proteins that are known to be relevant for COVID-19.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And here I provide a link, again, to actually a webpage from my institution, NILA, where we have a large initiative involving around 30 researchers that's actually trying to go about this and build a reinforcement learning agent that uses graph neural networks in order to design de novo molecules for COVID-19 and many of the things we're using there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I hope the website should be up to date now in terms of links to public code and so on.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So just to give you a quick sense of the challenges here and talk a little bit about why computational drug design, what we call de novo drug design, is not necessarily the only way that we can try to use these techniques to help, is first off, it just really takes a very long time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what I'm showing here in the top figure is the typical drug development pipeline
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: which essentially, first off, you figure out, say, what is the protein or pathway you want to target.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then there's somewhere between three and 20 years of trying to figure out what is a small molecule that might work for that.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then you have another maybe seven or so years of trying to figure out how to bring this into trials and get it approved.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The goal here with using machine learning
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and reinforcement learning and graph neural nets to help this is really reducing this big finding a promising molecule part of the problem, this lead discovery, as they call it, from something that's more of a decade to something that's maybe half a year.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But it's important to note that we still need to do clinical trials.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We still have to do a lot of biological assays.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So even if we're able to reduce the time it takes to find a promising molecule by an order of magnitude,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The hope with these is that we can come up with something that's highly effective in the couple years time frame, but really actually having this make an impact in the immediate future is less realistic just because of the trials that you have to do in terms of making sure it's safe.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the other type of approach that people do instead of trying to design new drugs, you try to do more what we call treatment design.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So here, there's really two types of approaches.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: One is let's try to leverage known structural information about the protein structure and then try to infer from this 3D structure what might be good, say, existing drugs that might attack this protein or bind with this protein.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the methodology for this style, again here, where we're not trying to design a new drug, but just find some treatments that already are out there and approved that could help, is we basically use the same technology that I was talking about in the last few minutes, but we try to apply them on existing drugs rather than generating new drugs.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The other type of approach and what I'll spend the bulk of the remaining time on is what we call a network-based approach, which is where we're actually trying to leverage the complex heterogeneous network of biological interactions between drugs, diseases, and proteins, and to use all this information to infer what might be useful drugs that we can repurpose or other treatment strategies that we can employ.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So again, the idea here is we can really think of the interactions between proteins, the interactions between proteins and diseases, the interactions between drugs and diseases, the polypharmacy side effects or efficacies that you see with drugs in terms of when you take drugs together, what happens.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We can think of all of these different biological interactions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: interactions as being embedded within a large heterogeneous network.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And our goal in some sense is to infer relationships that we haven't observed yet within this network.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we view this as what we call a relation prediction problem where we're trying to infer missing relationships.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it's important to note that I'm talking about this in the context of drug repurposing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But this idea of trying to analyze these large heterogeneous networks and predict missing information in them is also analogous for many applications that are relevant to COVID-19.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for example, epidemiological forecasting, trying to look at
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: not just drug repurposing, but trying to understand, for example, what might be other proteins you might want to look into and do more assays on.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: All these different things can be often represented as network or graph problems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the key intuition here when it comes to drug repurposing is that we can think of diseases as really being kind of embedded within a subgraph of proteins that they're interacting with within the interactome.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we can think of drugs similarly as being interacting with a subgraph of proteins.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we have this heterogeneous network and really one of the classic ways that people try to approach computational drug repurposing is trying to find overlaps between these subgraphs within the interactome network.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So trying to find drugs and diseases that have an overlapping interaction subgraph within the interactome.
